Posts.Title: Medical Exemption Certificate

Posts.Content: Hi Babs This is the advice i can give you following my right breast mastectomy back in March:-   1. Drink lots and lots of water, this really helps your recovery. The hospital monitor what goes in and what comes out so the more you drink the faster, fingers crossed, you will get home. 2. You will need to do physio as soon as you get out of hospital. This will help with the movement in your arm but also help prevent the scar attaching itself to your chest wall, not good if you want a reconstruction in the future. 3. The drain is a little uncomfortable but you get used to it. 4. Stay positive as this phase really is one of the easiest to cope with, you may not think so now, but if you are having chemo you will know what i mean xx 5. Buy some E45 and some Bio Oil (i use one from PAI called Bio regenerate and it is working it's magic) as you need to keep your skin moisturised and the Bio Oil helps reduce the scarring. 6. The nuclear dye is an interesting one, stings for a little bit but you soon forget this. If i think of anything else then i will email you but you will be fine. Buy some zinc pills and pop 2 and this should stop the cold symptoms, we had tried and tested this and it really does work. Good luck for tomorrow and keep smiling lovely Babs this is the start of your journey to getting you back to normality xxxx

Posts.Content: HI Coot   I too had a single mastectomy......didn't really get on with the softie so wore a scarf to cover my missing booby. The prosthesis is much better, as weighted, and you really wouldn't notice the difference from the outside. My physio said that you need to wear the weighted prosthesis as much as possible otherwise your muscles will form differently in your torso. Then if you do have a recon you may get some back pain as your body isn't used to having the boob. Hope that makes sense!!! My recon is delayed as my surgeon said he wants all other treatments out of the way first. This is due to preserving the skin as best as possible (hence having 25 rad sessions at a slightly lower dose) and recon most probably won't happen for atleast a year after rads finish. I bought some mastectomy bras but to be honest the best bra i have found to hold my prosthesis in place in the seamless bra...it is amazing and looks so much more natural and is SOOOOO much cheaper!!!. I have just bought another 6 in nude, black and white. I defo would recommend these instead of the mastectomy bras as the prosthesis moves a little in the pocket and rises up and i do feel a little conscious when this happens, but not with the seamless bra...........maybe i have found my new job in life to go into promotion of these seamless bras...yeah xxx Well my chemo is now over, yippee, just rads to start on 24th Sept (tattooing this Thurs:-/ ) and then relax until recon. Posts.Title: 1st chemo today...today I start fighting back!

Posts.Content: Hi Sue They found cancer in my sentinol node as well so 3 weeks after my MX i went back for a full clearance. I was only in for 3 days and only had my drain in at hospital, which is good because that was pretty uncomfortable but bearable. Within a week to 10 days all the dressings came off and it looked really neat. The main thing you need to do is your excercises, which are necessary to prevent you getting stiffness, cording and lymphoedema. If you can find a physio or nurse that specialises in these areas you can then work together to prevent any flare ups that you might have with your arm as once the lymph nodes are gone you have not much protection from infection. So you need to look after your arm really well. If you get a cut put savlon on it, it you get a hang nail don't pull it - cut it and put savlon on. Prevention is better than cure so i always have a mini medi bag that i cary with me that has savlon, plasters, antisepti wipes, insect bite stick etc etc. I also use PAI bio oil on my scars and it has worked wonders as they are so nice looking now and to be truthful the surgeon made the cut for my ANC just into the armpit so you really can't see it when you have a short t shirt or top on. So all is good and you are in the driving seat for your recovery......so don't do 100 miles an hour and think it should all be ok after a couple of weeks.....remember we all heal differently so listen to your body but keep up the excercises as they will help you tons for your movement in your arm. Also drink lots of water on this journey but anymore questions then please fire away and good luck with your op. xxxxx All the best SaxxyD xxxx
Posts.Title: Lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Hi Pollycat I too have had all my lymph nodes removed on my right side..........and yes you are right heavy lifting can bring on swelling so you must take care of your arm all the time. I just see it as a new me doing things in a different way as this is my life now so don't get frustrated or scared.,.......you just need to rethink how you do things. These are a couple of the things i have changed so far:- Food shopping - used to do - weekly shop thinking nothing of carrying 4 bags at a time from the car to the house and over load my arms. new way - 3 weekly shop online for all items except fresh fruit, bread etc (you know the things you like to see and feel before you buy) plus every other day do a little light shop for these other items which i carry in my left arm. Gardening - used to do - a whole day in the garden weeding, mowing, chopping bushes etc and having a very enjoyable time. new way - hubby now mows the lawn as too heavy for me to push, my best friend (who loves gardening) now helps me weed, chop bushes etc. I can normally only do an hour or so of light duties before my arm aches but then i make the tea/coffee and still have an enjoyable time. As you can see just from the couple of examples above that changes need to be made but you can still have fun :-) You just need to be mindful not to over do things and avoid lots of repetition as this too can flare the swelling up. My hubby massages my arm to do manual drainage daily and he can get the arm thinner by up to over an inch and once he has done that the aching does subside. So if you don't know how to do manual drainage then please find a physio that can teach you as prevention is better than cure. I defo do not want an arm that is massive compared to the other because the fluid has been left to build up - bite size chunks are needed to avoid this. Hope this helps you understand that things have to change after this type of operation but you can still have lots of fun doing things xxxx Let me know what changes you make as some may help me and others on here xxx Keep smiling lovely lady xxxx

Do you have a partner that would be happy to do your manual drainage for you, if you do then ask for them to be shown how to do it. I have mine done while we watch TV. If i have a rebellious day and i leave my sleeve off.....boy do i pay the price in the evening. So this is done very rarely now. The best advice i can give is seek a specialist in lymphoedema local to you....if you live in Kent let me know and i will pass you onto two ladies that look after me, sadly my hubby is not available to rent :-) I did find that if i wore the compression sleeve that finished at the wrist my hand would swell up so i now have the combined one that goes over the thumb. You may find that this could help you too? Thank goodness we can get the compression garments on our medical exemption card as you will find you will need to replace them every few months. I use my old ones when i work on my art as it doesn't matter if they get grubby and bobbly. They can get covered in paint or pastels and keep me happy doing what i love. I really hope this helps but if you need to ask anymore questions please let me know. Big Hugs SaxxyD

Posts.Title: Worrying scan results

Posts.Title: fluid filled lung

Posts.Content: Great to hear the op went well. There are a couple of things you could do for him to make him more comfortable. Do you have a small soft pillow? He can use this to rest under his arm to take some of the weight when his arm is down. Plus also my parents bought me a soft V shaped pillow and this helped me sleep at night. Keep a note of what pills he takes and when as he doesn't want to take the pain killers at the wrong time....and boy did this help us as we would both of forgotten...and goodness knows what that could of led to xx I didn't fancy a lot to eat so homemade soups were good as packed full of goodness, even if he only has a small cup full.. Get lots of bottled water in as he needs to keep up his fluids. Don't panic if a seroma appears (small fluid filled lump) under his arm, it will feel like he is holding a tennis ball under there....not nice but all he needs to do is ask them to drain it for him. I had mine drained 3 times and all was good after that. Lots of TLC but please also make sure you look after yourself as it is easy to forget about the person doing all the caring and running around xxx Also have you got a medical exemption card for him yet as he will now qualify for one. No more fees to pay YEAH.....got to some perks to having the big C lol xx Oh just thought......in hospital ask your hubby if he would prefer you to give him a bed bath instead of the nurses.......i'm glad my hubby did it for me. Bye for now lovely Wendle xxxxx
